(Id.). Arizona National Guard Historical Society and Arizona Military Museum The Articles of Incorporation for the Arizona National Guard Historical Society were executed on March 28%comma% 1975. In April 1981%comma% the General Staff dedicated the space for the East Room of the museum. On September 12%comma% 1981%comma% the Arizona Military Museum had its grand opening. Henderson Libraries seeks to cultivate a literate community by providing every citizen free access to books and information resources%comma% as well as state of the art technology that supports work%comma% school and recreational activities.

Henderson Libraries was established in 1943 in Downtown Henderson after a petition to create the Henderson School Public Library was introduced. Seven years later%comma% its first Children's Summer Reading Program was introduced. Through the years Henderson Libraries has continued to offer innovative children's programming - increasing children's interest in the library both today and into the future. That interest%comma% combined with the growing number of new homes in the community%comma% resulted in the purchase and renovation of the library district's first permanent building. The building program began in February 1953.

%newline%

In a major overhaul of education laws%comma% the Henderson School Public Library became a county library district in 1956 during a special session of the Nevada Legislature. At that time%comma% statutes were written to convert school library districts to county library districts. Subsequent to 1967%comma% several additional library districts were formed including Clark County Library District%comma% Pahrump%comma% Smokey Valley%comma% Amargosa%comma% and Tonopah. Henderson and Boulder City Library Districts remained as previously formed in 1956.

%newline%

Henderson Libraries cooperates with the other public libraries in Southern Nevada%comma% the Nevada System of Higher Education%comma% the Clark County School District and all other libraries around the state to provide quality library services to Nevada's residents.

Name: Utah Department of Administrative Services - Division of Administrative Rules
Text:
%newline%

The Division of Administrative Rules is an executive branch agency under the Department of Administrative Services.

%newline%

Administrative rulemaking was first centralized in Utah in 1973. This action followed a national trend that began in 1935 with the passage of the Federal Register Act%comma% and in 1946 with the passage of the federal Administrative Procedure Act. Prior to 1973%comma% individual agencies in Utah used their own processes for issuing rules. In 1973%comma% the Legislature passed the Utah Administrative Rule Making (sic) Act (Chapter 172%comma% Laws of Utah 1973) and charged the State Archivist with the responsibility for receiving rule filings and publishing rules.

%newline%

In 1985%comma% to heighten awareness of administrative rules and to address what appeared to be a lack of attention by the executive branch with regard to the regulatory process%comma% the Legislature assigned the rulemaking functions to the Office of Administrative Rules%comma% with a State Rulemaking Coordinator answering to the State Archivist as part of a recodification of the entire process (Chapter 158%comma% Laws of Utah 1985). In 1987%comma% to further emphasize the importance of rulemaking and to secure funding for publication%comma% the Legislature changed the 'Office' designation to 'Division'. The director reports to the Executive Director of the Department of Administrative Services (a cabinet department) (Chapter 241%comma% Laws of Utah 1987).

%newline%
